titleStmt.title: Letter from Ina Coolbrith to John G. Neihardt, April 4, 1913
titleStmt.author: Coolbrith, Ina D. (Ina Donna), 1841-1928

publicationStmt.authority: The Papers of John G. Neihardt

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Coolbrith, Ina D. (Ina Donna), 1841-1928
bibl.title: Letter from Ina Coolbrith to John G. Neihardt

revisionDesc.change: Weakly, Laura K. Review; Additional Encoding

div1.p:
I wonder if you have any respect for this woman, much less "veneration for the poet" remaining! I was stunned to-day to find in a package of unaswered letters, put away when I fell ill last June by my house-
6
companion, and certainly overlooked, your letter of June 26 — 1912!! Now what can I say or do? I beg your pardon: would do so on my knees if it did not hurt so. Besides, I think it undignified to pray standing and look up. I am ill a great deal, being nearly at a time to don a new body or pass into oblivion and its "breakdown" which kept your letter from me lasted from June last to January '13.

You were to take charge of the literary department of the Minneapolis Journal in September, eight months ago, and I suppose the length of time has farred me out. If not, I'll try to drag out some dates upon hearing from you. Write me anyway, and tell me you forgive, now that you understand. I reach out warm hands to the "Builders" of the new generation, — for, alas! have I not seen
7
nearly all of mine pass into the silence.
Bret Harte, Mark Twain, Prentice Mulford, Charley Stoddard, Joaquin Miller — friends of a lifetime. I am the last of my Clan.
